label.text: Superworms
A species of ‘superworm’, Zophobas morio, has bacteria in its intestine that can biodegrade plastic into smaller molecules that the superworms can digest.
Researchers are investigating if superworms could be used to remove plastic waste.
Researchers wanted to determine if the superworms could survive and grow solely on the energy from the plastic broken down by the bacteria in their intestine. They set up three feeding groups:
3 sets of 15 superworms fed with oat bran (a type of cereal)
3 sets of 15 superworms fed with polystyrene (a type of plastic)
3 sets of 15 superworms that were not fed (control group).
The average superworm mass in each feeding group was determined at intervals for 29 days.
The graph below shows the results of the investigation.
bran
polystyrene
control
Which of the following statements are supported by the data in the graph?
Select ‘Supported’ or ‘Not supported’ for each statement.
Oat bran provides more energy for worm growth than polystyrene.
Worms in the control group died after 29 days without food.
Worms can obtain energy from polystyrene.
Polystyrene is more toxic than oat bran.
What does the vertical dashed line at day 8 in the graph most likely indicate?
The three groups received the same feed until day 8.
The fastest average mass gain in any feeding group occurred in the first 8 days.
All superworms had an identical change in mass until day 8.
There were no bacteria in the superworms’ intestines until day 8.
The aim of this research was to determine if the superworms could be used to remove plastic pollution.
To achieve this aim, four possible changes to the original experiment are presented below.
Which one of these changes would provide the most useful information about the use of the superworms to remove plastic pollution?
Extend the duration of the experiment to 58 days.
Replace the superworms with a range of related species.
Replace the polystryrene in the experiment with a range of other plastics.
Measure the mass of food that is remaining at the end of the day rather than measuring the mass of the superworms.
What type of relationship exists between the superworms and their intestinal bacteria?
commensalism: superworms benefit, bacteria recieve no benefit but do not get harmed
parasitism: bacteria benefit, superworms get harmed
mutualism: both superworms and bacteria benefit
predation: superworms feed on bacteria
